criteria: Ability to set up a coordinate plane and accurately plot given points.
Application of distance formula and slope to prove geometric properties.
Logical reasoning and justification in proving geometric theorems.
Ability to use circle theorems related to coordinate geometry.
descriptions: Student is unable to set up a coordinate plane or plot points accurately.
Student struggles to set up a coordinate plane and plots points with significant errors.
Student sets up a coordinate plane with minor inaccuracies and makes some errors in plotting points.
Student accurately sets up a coordinate plane and plots most points correctly with only minor errors.
Student accurately sets up a coordinate plane and plots all points correctly.
Student accurately and efficiently sets up a coordinate plane and plots all points correctly, demonstrating a clear understanding of coordinate geometry principles.
Student does not attempt to use distance formula or slope to prove geometric properties.
Student attempts to use distance formula or slope but demonstrates significant errors in calculations or application.
Student uses distance formula and slope but makes several errors, hindering the proof.
Student correctly applies distance formula and slope with minor errors, partially supporting the proof.
Student correctly applies distance formula and slope to prove geometric properties with few or no errors.
Student skillfully applies distance formula and slope to rigorously prove geometric properties, demonstrating a deep understanding of the underlying concepts.
Student provides no logical reasoning or justification for their claims.
Student attempts to provide reasoning but it is unclear, illogical, or irrelevant.
Student provides some reasoning but it is incomplete or contains logical flaws.
Student provides mostly clear and logical reasoning to support their claims, with minor gaps.
Student provides clear, logical, and well-supported reasoning to justify their proof.
Student provides exceptionally clear, concise, and insightful reasoning, demonstrating a comprehensive understanding of geometric theorem proving and offering alternative perspectives or approaches.
Student does not demonstrate any understanding or application of circle theorems.
Student attempts to apply circle theorems but shows significant misunderstanding.
Student recalls and states circle theorems but struggles to apply them correctly in the context of coordinate geometry.
Student applies basic circle theorems with some accuracy but may struggle with more complex scenarios or theorems.
Student accurately applies relevant circle theorems to solve problems and prove statements.
Student expertly applies circle theorems, demonstrating a nuanced understanding of their relationship to coordinate geometry and provides creative solutions.
